expanded_description: Analyzing limits and continuity of piecewise-defined functions, including evaluation at boundary points and determining parameters for continuity.

core_concept.explanation: A piecewise function is defined by different formulas on different intervals of its domain. When evaluating limits and continuity, we must pay special attention to boundary points where the function definition changes, as these are the only locations where discontinuities can occur.

image.alt: Graph showing a piecewise function with different formulas on different intervals
image.caption: Figure 25: A piecewise function uses different rules on different parts of its domain.

sections.introduction: Piecewise functions are essential in mathematics and real-world applications where different rules apply in different situations. Understanding how to work with these functions is crucial for limit and continuity analysis.

image.alt: Multiple examples of piecewise functions with different configurations
image.caption: Figure 26: Various piecewise function configurations showing different boundary behaviors.

key_concept.definition: A piecewise function is defined by multiple sub-functions, where each sub-function applies to a specific interval of the domain. The general form is: $f(x) = \begin{cases} f_1(x) & \text{if } x \in I_1 \\ f_2(x) & \text{if } x \in I_2 \\ \vdots & \vdots \\ f_n(x) & \text{if } x \in I_n \end{cases}$
key_concept.context: Each piece $f_i(x)$ is called a sub-function, and the intervals $I_i$ partition the domain.

principles.statement: Discontinuities in piecewise functions can only occur at boundary points where the definition changes.
principles.application: Focus limit and continuity analysis on boundary points; interior points of each piece follow standard continuity rules.
principles.analogy: Like border crossings between countries—the rules change at the boundary, not within each country.

principles.statement: The inequality symbols ($<$, $\leq$, $>$, $\geq$) determine which piece applies at boundary points.
principles.application: Pay careful attention to whether boundary points are included ($\leq$ or $\geq$) or excluded ($<$ or $>$).
principles.analogy: Like a VIP rope at an event—being on one side or the other determines which rules apply to you.

sections.introduction: When evaluating limits of piecewise functions, the key is selecting the correct sub-function based on the direction of approach relative to boundary points.

process_flow.result: Target point identified for limit evaluation.

image.alt: Graph with target point marked on x-axis
image.caption: Step 1: Mark the target $x$-value $c$.

process_flow.process: Determine if point is a boundary
process_flow.description: Check if $c$ is where the function definition changes.
process_flow.result: If boundary, use one-sided limits; if interior, use direct substitution.

image.alt: Diagram showing boundary vs interior points
image.caption: Step 2: Determine if $c$ is a boundary point.

process_flow.description: For left-hand limit, use the piece for $x < c$. For right-hand limit, use the piece for $x > c$.

image.alt: Highlighting which piece applies to each direction
image.caption: Step 3: Match direction to correct piece.

process_flow.description: Calculate $\lim_{x \to c^-} f(x)$ and $\lim_{x \to c^+} f(x)$ using the selected pieces.

image.alt: Calculation of one-sided limits shown
image.caption: Step 4: Evaluate limits from each direction.

process_flow.description: If one-sided limits are equal, the two-sided limit exists and equals that value.
process_flow.result: Two-sided limit existence and value determined.

image.alt: Comparison of one-sided limits
image.caption: Step 5: Compare one-sided limits to determine two-sided limit.

worked_examples.title: Limit at a Boundary Point
worked_examples.problem: Given $f(x) = \begin{cases} 2x - 1 & x < 3 \\ x^2 - 4 & x \geq 3 \end{cases}$, evaluate $\lim_{x \to 3} f(x)$.

step_by_step.step: Identify that x = 3 is a boundary point
step_by_step.explanation: The function definition changes at $x = 3$, so we need one-sided limits.
For $x \to 3^+$, we have $x > 3$, so use $f(x) = x^2 - 4$.
Both one-sided limits equal 5, so the two-sided limit exists.

worked_examples.concept_applied: When one-sided limits agree at a boundary point, the two-sided limit exists.

image.alt: Graph showing piecewise function with matching limits at x=3
image.caption: Figure 27: Both pieces approach $y = 5$ at $x = 3$, so the limit exists.

worked_examples.title: Limit Where One-Sided Limits Differ
worked_examples.problem: Given $f(x) = \begin{cases} x + 2 & x < 1 \\ 3x & x \geq 1 \end{cases}$, evaluate $\lim_{x \to 1} f(x)$.

step_by_step.step: Identify that x = 1 is a boundary point

step_by_step.explanation: Both limits equal 3, so the two-sided limit exists.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Even with different formulas, limits can agree at boundary points.

worked_examples.title: Limit at an Interior Point
worked_examples.problem: Given $f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2 & x < 2 \\ 3x - 1 & x \geq 2 \end{cases}$, evaluate $\lim_{x \to 0} f(x)$.

step_by_step.step: Identify that x = 0 is NOT a boundary point
step_by_step.explanation: The boundary is at $x = 2$, so $x = 0$ is in the interior of the first piece.
Polynomial functions are continuous, so substitute directly.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Interior points of pieces don't require one-sided limit analysis.

image.alt: Graph showing limit at interior point away from boundary
image.caption: Figure 28: At interior points, use the piece containing that point directly.

sections.introduction: A piecewise function is continuous at a boundary point if the limit exists, the function is defined, and the limit equals the function value. This requires careful verification of all three continuity conditions.

image.alt: Diagram showing continuous vs discontinuous piecewise functions at boundaries
image.caption: Figure 29: Continuous piecewise functions have no gaps at boundary points.

key_concept.definition: A piecewise function is continuous at a boundary point $x = c$ if: (1) $f(c)$ is defined, (2) $\lim_{x \to c} f(x)$ exists, and (3) $\lim_{x \to c} f(x) = f(c)$.
key_concept.context: Since each piece is typically continuous on its interior, we only need to check continuity at boundary points.

process_flow.description: List all $x$-values where the function definition changes.
process_flow.result: Complete list of points requiring continuity checks.

image.alt: Piecewise function with boundaries marked
image.caption: Step 1: Mark all boundary points.

process_flow.description: Use the piece with $\leq$ or $\geq$ to find the actual function value.

image.alt: Showing which piece defines f(c)
image.caption: Step 2: Determine $f(c)$ from the appropriate piece.

process_flow.description: Use the piece for $x < c$ to find $\lim_{x \to c^-} f(x)$.

image.alt: Left-hand limit calculation
image.caption: Step 3: Calculate limit from the left.

process_flow.description: Use the piece for $x > c$ to find $\lim_{x \to c^+} f(x)$.

image.alt: Right-hand limit calculation
image.caption: Step 4: Calculate limit from the right.

process_flow.description: Check: limit exists, $f(c)$ defined, and limit equals $f(c)$.
process_flow.result: Continuity status determined at each boundary.

image.alt: Checklist for continuity verification
image.caption: Step 5: Verify all three continuity conditions.

worked_examples.title: Verifying Continuity at a Boundary
worked_examples.problem: Determine if $f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2 + 1 & x < 2 \\ 3x - 1 & x \geq 2 \end{cases}$ is continuous at $x = 2$.

step_by_step.step: Check condition 3: Limit equals function value

worked_examples.concept_applied: All three continuity conditions must be verified at boundary points.

image.alt: Graph showing continuous piecewise function at x=2
image.caption: Figure 30: The pieces connect smoothly at $x = 2$, making the function continuous.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Discontinuity in a Piecewise Function
worked_examples.problem: Determine if $g(x) = \begin{cases} 2x + 3 & x < 1 \\ x^2 & x \geq 1 \end{cases}$ is continuous at $x = 1$.

step_by_step.explanation: Left limit (5) ≠ Right limit (1), so the two-sided limit does not exist.

worked_examples.concept_applied: When one-sided limits differ, the function has a jump discontinuity.

image.alt: Graph showing jump discontinuity at x=1
image.caption: Figure 31: The pieces do not connect at $x = 1$, creating a jump discontinuity.

worked_examples.title: Continuity Over an Entire Domain
worked_examples.problem: Determine where $h(x) = \begin{cases} x + 1 & x < 0 \\ x^2 & 0 \leq x < 3 \\ 6 & x \geq 3 \end{cases}$ is continuous.

step_by_step.explanation: Each piece is continuous on its interior; discontinuities at boundaries.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Piecewise functions may have multiple discontinuities at different boundaries.

image.alt: Graph showing discontinuities at multiple boundary points
image.caption: Figure 32: Discontinuities occur at both $x = 0$ and $x = 3$.

sections.introduction: A common problem type involves finding unknown constants that make a piecewise function continuous. This requires setting up equations based on the continuity conditions.

key_concept.definition: To make a piecewise function continuous at a boundary, set the left-hand limit equal to the right-hand limit (and both equal to $f(c)$ if defined).
key_concept.context: This creates an equation that can be solved for the unknown parameter.

principles.statement: For continuity at $x = c$: $\lim_{x \to c^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to c^+} f(x) = f(c)$.
principles.application: Set the two piece expressions equal at the boundary to solve for parameters.
principles.analogy: Like adjusting two puzzle pieces so they fit together perfectly at the seam.

worked_examples.title: Finding One Parameter for Continuity
worked_examples.problem: Find the value of $k$ that makes $f(x) = \begin{cases} kx + 2 & x < 4 \\ 3x - 6 & x \geq 4 \end{cases}$ continuous at $x = 4$.

step_by_step.explanation: For continuity, left limit must equal right limit at $x = 4$.
Set the limits equal and solve.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Equating one-sided limits creates an equation to solve for unknown parameters.

image.alt: Graph showing piecewise function continuous with k=1
image.caption: Figure 33: With $k = 1$, the pieces connect at $x = 4$.

worked_examples.title: Finding Two Parameters for Continuity
worked_examples.problem: Find $a$ and $b$ so that $f(x) = \begin{cases} ax + 1 & x < 2 \\ 3 & x = 2 \\ x^2 + b & x > 2 \end{cases}$ is continuous at $x = 2$.

step_by_step.explanation: Left limit = Right limit = Function value = 3.

step_by_step.step: Use left limit to find a
Use right limit to find b

step_by_step.explanation: Check that all three values equal 3.

worked_examples.final_answer: $a = 1$ and $b = -1$ make the function continuous at $x = 2$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Multiple parameters require multiple equations from continuity conditions.

image.alt: Graph showing piecewise function continuous with a=1, b=-1
image.caption: Figure 34: With $a = 1$ and $b = -1$, all three pieces meet at $(2, 3)$.

worked_examples.title: Continuity at Multiple Boundaries
worked_examples.problem: Find $m$ and $n$ so that $f(x) = \begin{cases} mx + n & x < 1 \\ 2x + 1 & 1 \leq x < 3 \\ 5x - m & x \geq 3 \end{cases}$ is continuous everywhere.
worked_examples.final_answer: $m = 8$ and $n = -5$ make the function continuous everywhere
worked_examples.concept_applied: Multiple boundaries require a system of equations for continuity.

image.alt: Graph showing piecewise function continuous at all boundaries
image.caption: Figure 35: With $m = 8$ and $n = -5$, the function is continuous at all boundaries.

summary: Section 1.8 covered limits and continuity of piecewise functions. We learned that piecewise functions use different formulas on different intervals, and discontinuities can only occur at boundary points where the definition changes. To evaluate limits, we select the appropriate sub-function based on the direction of approach: left-hand limits use the $x < c$ piece, right-hand limits use the $x > c$ piece. For continuity at a boundary, all three conditions must be satisfied: (1) $f(c)$ is defined, (2) $\lim_{x \to c} f(x)$ exists (one-sided limits agree), and (3) $\lim_{x \to c} f(x) = f(c)$. We practiced finding unknown parameters that make piecewise functions continuous by setting one-sided limits equal and solving the resulting equations. Special piecewise functions include absolute value functions (continuous everywhere), step functions (jump discontinuities at integers), sign functions (jump at zero), and ramp functions (continuous with corner). Real-world applications include tax brackets, shipping costs, utility rates, and parking fees. Common pitfalls include using the wrong piece for a limit direction, ignoring the function value at boundaries, assuming continuity without verification, misreading inequality symbols, missing multiple boundaries, and making algebraic errors in parameter problems. Mastery of piecewise function analysis is essential for advanced calculus topics and modeling real-world scenarios with tiered structures.
